responses.content: Thank you for joining today's call. I'd like to start with a few comments on what we're seeing as we're coming out of the pandemic, both on the customer experience side and on the operating cost side in this current inflationary environment.
Worldwide net sales in Q1 were $116.4 billion, an increase of 9% year-over-year, excluding the impact of foreign exchange. This is the top end of our guidance range of $112 billion to $117 billion.
Our compound annual growth since before the pandemic stands at 25%, a growth rate higher than what we were seeing before the pandemic.

Our prime members continue to be a key driver of growth. Prime members have meaningfully increased their spend since the start of the pandemic, and we continue to see consistently high member renewal rates. We also added millions more new Prime members during the quarter.

Delivery speed performance is now approaching levels not seen since the months immediately preceding the pandemic in early 2020. We now have the widest selection ever available for Prime's fast delivery.

We've seen a large cost to keep up with demand these past two years. During this period, we doubled the size of our operations and nearly doubled our workforce to 1.6 million employees. However, we continue to face a variety of cost pressures in our consumer business, divided into externally driven costs, primarily inflation, and internally controllable costs, primarily productivity and fixed cost deleverage.

The externally driven costs are a result of intensifying inflationary pressures throughout Q1. Line haul air and ocean shipping rates continue to be at or above the rates in the second half of last year, which were already much higher than pre-COVID levels. The cost to ship in overseas containers more than doubled compared to pre-pandemic rates, and the cost of fuel is approximately 1.5 times higher than it was even a year ago. Combined with year-over-year increases in wage inflation, these pressures have added approximately $2 billion of incremental costs compared to last year.

Productivity and fixed cost leverage costs are more within our control. We faced a labor-constrained environment in the second half of 2021, and the emergence of the Omicron variant led to staffing challenges. This resulted in lower productivity, adding approximately $2 billion in costs compared to last year. We expect to reduce these cost headwinds in Q2 as productivity improves. Additionally, we have excess capacity in our fulfillment and transportation network, leading to $1 billion of additional costs year-over-year in Q1. We expect these effects to persist for the next several quarters as we adjust to the current capacity.

Combining externally driven and internally controllable costs, we have approximately $6 billion in incremental costs for the quarter. About two-thirds of these costs are within our control. Our guidance includes an expectation of incurring approximately $4 billion of these incremental costs in Q2.

AWS saw another strong quarter of growth with net sales of $18.4 billion in Q1, up 37% year-over-year, reaching an annualized sales run rate of nearly $74 billion. We continue to see strong demand from a diverse range of customers, including governments, not-for-profits, start-ups, and enterprises.

Capital investments were $61 billion for the trailing 12-month period ended March 31, with about 40% allocated to infrastructure supporting AWS and our consumer business, 30% to fulfillment capacity, and 25% to transportation. For full year 2022, we expect infrastructure spend to grow year-over-year, primarily to support AWS innovation. Fulfillment and transportation capital expenditures are expected to be lower or flat compared to the prior year.
We reported an overall net loss of $3.8 billion in Q1, which includes a pretax valuation loss of $7.6 billion from our investment in Rivian Automotive.

Our Q2 guidance accounts for seasonal step-up in stock-based compensation expense, expecting approximately $6 billion compared to $3.3 billion in Q1, reflecting wage inflation and continued hiring in high-demand areas.

Advertising revenue was up 25% year-over-year, demonstrating a strong run rate compared to overall revenue growth. We're pleased with the performance of our advertising team and the value it provides to sellers and vendors.

Our grocery formats, including Go Grocery and Amazon Fresh, are performing well with increasing customer interest. We continue to innovate with self-checkout capabilities and Just Walk Out technology, enhancing convenience and efficiency for our customers.

We recently hosted Amazon Accelerate, introducing new tools and capabilities for selling partners, including local selling options and global selling tools to facilitate U.S. third-party sellers expanding their offerings worldwide.

Our AWS backlog has grown significantly, reaching $88.9 billion as of March, up 68% year-over-year, with a weighted average remaining term of 3.8 years. This reflects continued strong demand and long-term commitments from our customers.

questions: In terms of the revenue guide for the June quarter, it implies about 3%. Historically, in non-COVID years, growth has been between 4% and 6%. Are you seeing signs of consumer softness or weakening? Is there any particular factor causing your sequential growth to be lower than typical?

Regarding margins for Q2, you have $4 billion in incremental costs versus $6 billion in the March quarter, yet your guidance year-over-year implies a similar margin decline of about 500 basis points. Could you explain this?
How do you plan to pass through higher input costs due to inflation through pricing? When can we start to see these changes?
Shipping costs are up 14% versus units flat. Are you seeing savings from bringing transportation in-house, and how do you view shipping costs relative to units?
With increased inventory selection for one-day and same-day delivery, are you seeing incremental sales based on this availability?
Regarding tech and content, with higher expenses despite lower AWS costs, are there other factors like Kuiper or non-revenue-generating projects affecting your modeling?
You mentioned running at excess fulfillment capacity. How long do you anticipate it will take to regain productivity and cost efficiencies in the fulfillment network?
Is the $4 billion incremental cost entirely separate from previous logistics and supply chain costs? How does this affect the permanent vs. transient nature of your cost structure?
Looking ahead, will fulfillment expenses and headcount build have a different cadence this year due to existing excess capacity compared to prior years?
International operating income is now consistently positive. What is driving this improvement? Are major builds complete, leading to fulfillment center efficiencies, or are there other factors?
Is supply chain disruption affecting your advertising business in any way?
Can you share numbers on AWS backlog growth this quarter versus last quarter?
